title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #900: Longest Path in Sparse Random Graphs**

There exists f:(1/2,∞)→ℝ with f(c)→0 as c→1/2 and f(c)→1 as c→∞, such that G(n,cn) has whp a path of length ≥f(c)n.

**Answer**: PROVED (Ajtai-Komlós-Szemerédi 1981)

title: Graph
content:
**Graph n** = SimpleGraph (Fin n)

A simple undirected graph on n labeled vertices.

title: Erdős-Rényi Model
content:
**G(n, m)**: Random graph with n vertices and exactly m edges.

Uniform distribution over all such graphs.

title: Path
content:
**IsPath(G, vs)**: A sequence of distinct vertices with consecutive adjacency.

vs.Nodup ∧ ∀ i, G.Adj vs[i] vs[i+1]

title: Path Length
content:
**pathLength(vs)** = |vs| - 1 = number of edges in the path.

The quantity we want to maximize.

title: Longest Path Length
content:
**longestPathLength(G)** = sup over all paths in G.

The central quantity of the problem.

title: With High Probability
content:
**whp**: An event holds with probability → 1 as n → ∞.

Standard notion in probabilistic combinatorics.

title: Whp in Sparse Random
content:
**WhpInSparseRandom(c, P)**: P holds whp in G(n, cn).

For all ε > 0, ∃ N such that n ≥ N ⟹ Prob[P] > 1 - ε.

title: Critical Density
content:
**c = 1/2**: The threshold for giant component emergence.

Average degree = 2c, so c = 1/2 means average degree 1.

title: Subcritical Forest
content:
**c < 1/2**: G(n, cn) is a forest whp.

No cycles, only trees. Paths are O(log n).

title: Supercritical Giant
content:
**c > 1/2**: A unique giant component of size Θ(n) emerges.

This allows for linear-length paths.

title: Path Length Function
content:
**f(c)**: The fraction of n achieved by longest path whp.

For c > 1/2, longest path ≈ f(c)·n.

title: f(c) → 0 at 1/2
content:
**lim_{c→1/2⁺} f(c) = 0**

Near the threshold, paths are short (o(n)).

title: f(c) → 1 at ∞
content:
**lim_{c→∞} f(c) = 1**

Dense graphs have nearly Hamiltonian paths.

title: f is Monotone
content:
**f is increasing on (1/2, ∞)**

More edges → longer paths.

title: AKS Theorem
content:
**Ajtai-Komlós-Szemerédi (1981)**:

G(n, cn) has whp a path of length ≥ f(c)·n.

The main result solving Erdős #900.

title: AKS Tight
content:
**Tightness**: The bound f(c)·n is essentially optimal.

Longest path ≈ f(c)·n (up to o(n) error).

title: Subcritical Path Length
content:
**c < 1/2**: Longest path is O(log n).

Forests have logarithmic diameter.

title: Hamiltonian Path
content:
**IsHamiltonianPath**: Path visiting every vertex exactly once.

The maximum possible path length = n - 1.

title: Hamiltonian Threshold
content:
**For c ≥ (log n)/2**: G(n, cn) has whp a Hamiltonian path.

The dense regime where f(c) → 1.

title: Rotation-Extension
content:
**Rotation-extension technique**: Key method in AKS proof.

Either extend path or path already covers all reachable vertices.

title: Erdős Conjecture
content:
**ErdosConjecture900**: ∃ f with the three required properties.

1. f(c) → 0 as c → 1/2
2. f(c) → 1 as c → ∞
3. G(n, cn) has whp path ≥ f(c)n

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #900: SOLVED**

The conjecture is TRUE.

Ajtai-Komlós-Szemerédi (1981) proved f(c) exists with all required properties.
